Thank you to each and every family!

Williston Public School District #1 recognizes the need that many students rely on school meals during the day and we will offer meals Monday through Friday during school closure. This starts Monday, March 23. FREE grab and go meals will be available for all students ages 1-18 from 11:30-12:30 Monday-Friday. The following locations will have meals:

· Bakken Elementary – pick up outside door 4.
· Hagan Elementary - pick up outside door 5
. McVay Elementary- on sidewalk in front of building
· Housing Authority Park – pick up on 4th Ave W (behind Williston Auto) – where Summer meals are served

Here are the details:
- Meals are available for any student 1-18 at all locations.
- Meals will be bagged and taken off site for consumption. Students will not be allowed inside any building.
- The student must be present to receive the meal. The meal will consist of an entrée, fruit, vegetable and milk.
- A grab and go breakfast will also be available for the student to take for the next day. All meals for students are FREE.

Preventative plans will build on everyday practices, encouraging hand hygiene, disinfecting classrooms, monitoring absenteeism, and communicating routinely. For further health concerns or questions regarding your child in school, please contact Lynn Douglas MSN, RN School Nurse Coordinator.

▪️Beds to hold Goldilocks and the 3 Bears
▪️Bridges from “Three Billy Goats Gruff”

Dear McVay families,

This message is to inform you that a note was found today at McVay Elementary School regarding a potential bomb threat. We are committed to the safety and education of all our students. We also want to clearly communicate with parents about safety issues when they arise.

Local law enforcement was notified immediately, determined an evacuation was not necessary, and searched the building. Nothing suspicious was found.

Classes will continue to resume as usual the rest of today and tomorrow. Counselors will be available if any students would like to talk to someone about this event.

All threats to our school or students are taken seriously and investigated thoroughly. We wanted you to have the facts so you can discuss them with your child and emphasize the seriousness of this issue. If you discover anything that can assist in the investigation, please contact us immediately.

Thank you to Samaritan's Feet, Thrivent, and all of the other amazing volunteers for giving kids a gift of hope, kindness, and a pair of awesome shoes!

McVay 4th graders went on strike for more ice cream as an engaging lesson in peacefully standing up for rights.

Before the protest, they learned about Cesar Chavez and his role in forming the National Farm Workers Association. They learned about the working conditions and low pay of migrant farm workers in California, which resulted in Chavez leading a strike against grape growers in 1965.

After a negotiation with Principal Brenner, students agreed to work hard and be positive role models, in exchange for ice cream sandwiches!

May 4, 2019 at 1:12 AM ·

All students have officially been released to parents. I would like to thank our administrative team and our tech department for your assistance by sending messages through School Messenger with today's course of events. I'd like to thank our staff from each building who rose to the occasion and made the best of circumstances. I'd like to thank our students and parents for your patience as well.

Monday morning, our district leadership team and SROs will be debriefing about the scope and sequence of events. Then, principals, coordinators, and directors will do the same with their buildings and departments.

Thank you to law enforcement for your quick response and for apprehending the suspect who caused all of this!

The fifty-one WHS students from The Holocaust: History and Memory course are holding a community event on May 16th. Come support these hard-working students by attending the History Fair.

This is the first time this elective course for upper classman has been offered at WHS. Last summer, Kari Hall was the first North Dakota teacher to attend extensive Holocaust education training at The Olga Lengyel Institute for Holocaust Studies and Human Rights in NYC. The TOLI training is designed to foster Holocaust education with time spent with survivors and testimonies as a legacy of Holocaust survivor Olga Lengyel. We want to share out with our community that “never again begins with you.”
